subtitles_text: >> JEFF: Previously on Survivor:
The former Kucha tribe, outnumbered by Ogakor's
alliance, fought to stay alive by exploiting the tribe's
disdain for Jerri. >> ELISABETH: I think there's a
crack in the tribe right now. Jerri-- I think she's going to
get votes from their tribe. >> JEFF: Jerri won the reward
challenge and chose Amber to share in her victory, while back
at camp, Barramundi had their own celebration without them.
>> KEITH: What's missing? What's making it feel that way?
The Wicked Witch of the West isn't here.
( Jerri laughing ) >> JEFF: Keith won immunity for
the second time in a row. ( thunder crashing )
The tribe hiked to tribal council in a torrential
rainstorm... Alicia.
...where the former Kucha members learned that Ogakor's
alliance was still strong. The tribe has spoken.
Alicia was voted out, becoming the first member of the jury.
Eight are left. Who will be the next to go?
>> COLBY: Last night it was just tossing and turning all night.
The floor of the tent was uncomfortable.
When the rain started coming in, I was on the end, started
getting some water flow in my side of the tent, just draining
off the tarp that we lay on. And then wake up to see the rain
like this, our fire's out. It's going to be a long day.
>> JERRI: Right now my main concern is staying dry, 'cause I
don't want to get cold. So I'm just feeling kind of
drained and lazy right now. So... I'm sleeping in.
>> ELISABETH: It's a beautiful day in the neighborhood.
>> RODGER: Yeah, maybe it'll clear off.
Maybe it'll only rain half the day.
>> AMBER: I hope our sunny days aren't completely gone though.
>> ELISABETH: The rainy season is upon us.
>> KEITH: They don't call me fireman for nothing.
>> NICK: Look at that. Look at that.
>> KEITH: The physical work is not light.
You've got to go get wood, you've got to break it down,
you've got to keep the fire going.
And life in the outback is tough, and it's getting tougher.
It really is getting tougher for everybody.
( Nick gargling ) >> ELISABETH: What are you
doing, Nick? >> NICK: I swear, every time I
swallow my throat just burns. The roof of my mouth feels like
it's been burned for the last three days.
>> ELISABETH: You have large taste buds?
>> NICK: Enlarged. >> ELISABETH: Wow.
>> NICK: I had in, like, three or four enlarged taste buds on
my tongue, which just is terrible.
And I'm feeling better, but my mouth is still raw, so I can't
even drink water normally, and it's just, like, ugh.
>> TINA: Sure doesn't look like the spring water from home.
>> RODGER: No, that looks dirty. >> NICK: That's 'cause the
river's so muddy. If it's been boiled, then I'll
drink it. We're out of water.
>> RODGER: We better... we need to definitely boil up some
water. >> NICK: Just dump it and get
some more. >> RODGER: Yeah.
>> TINA: The rain settled in here and it muddied our water,
and it's so cloudy, that fishing has not been good at all.
We've lost all but two of our hooks because we have to fish
from shore and there's a lot of debris on the bottom.
>> RODGER: Tina, would you come down here?
I'm going to have to get out of the water.
I've got a line hung up. >> TINA: You got a line stuck?
>> RODGER: Yeah, about two feet offshore here.
The water's just so much muddier.
Of course I'm taking a chance on losing my hook in here, I do
know that. Let me poke this way...
Maybe tomorrow, we got a full day, maybe the water will clear
up a little bit... >> TINA: Yeah.
>> RODGER: ...and try to get some fishing.
Something besides rice. >> COLBY: Because we're not
having the fish, we're having to rely on our rice.
We're eating a lot more rice than maybe we should be.
We're down to about two or three days supply at the rate we're
going. We still have eight people to
feed. Keith, you want me to start the
rice in ten minutes? >> KEITH: Yeah, if Jerri's up
for that. >> AMBER: Or we could do the two
cups of rice, it doesn't matter. >> ELISABETH: Maybe go back to
the two cups. >> JERRI: One more meal of rice
is all we have left. >> AMBER: At the most.
>> COLBY: Ooh. >> ELISABETH: Oh, my gosh, I
knew it was going to be something fun.
>> COLBY: A rope ladder. >> ELISABETH: Oh, my gosh.
>> COLBY: Oh, my gosh. Hey, guys, you guys are going
to dig this one. >> ELISABETH: It's gonna be a
good one. >> COLBY: They have upped the
ante. It came on a rope ladder.
It says "Mental or physical, you never can tell.
But you'll need a partner so, you must pair up well.
One guy, one girl, one reward to split.
If there's one reward to win, then this one is it."
( exclaiming happily ) >> Wow!
>> COLBY: So we're splitting the reward, and this one is going to
be big and chunky. >> TINA: A good one.
>> ELISABETH: How do you guys think we should decide partners?
>> AMBER: I don't know. Should we pull them out of the
hat? >> COLBY: You want to do that?
>> JERRI: I don't think so. >> ELISABETH: You don't want to
pull out of a hat? >> JERRI: No.
I think we should pick. >> ELISABETH: Who would you
pick? >> JERRI: I'd pick Colby.
>> TINA: Well, duh, who wouldn't?
>> JERRI: Well, the whole thing is, you know, when did this game
start being fair? >> TINA: No, but I think it is
about team-manship. >> RODGER: I'm the old guy here,
I know nobody wants to be with me, but you know...
>> AMBER: Oh, Rodger! >> RODGER: Sometimes you've just
got to go with the flow. >> TINA: How we going to do it,
Colby? >> COLBY: I've got all the guys'
names written on a piece of paper.
>> AMBER: And the girls pick? >> COLBY: Yep.
>> AMBER: Don't open it yet, till we all get one.
>> TINA: Did I get one? >> COLBY: Yep, you got it.
Don't look at them yet. All right, you can look at them.
>> AMBER: Keith, you're my partner!
>> ELISABETH: Nick, you're my partner.
>> JERRI: Colby. >> TINA: Oh, my goodness.
>> ELISABETH: That's funny. ( scattered chuckling )
>> COLBY: Ready to rock? >> JERRI: Yeah.
Ironically enough, I ended up being Colby's partner, anyway.
I think it's important that people are constantly reminded
of the reality of our situation. There's nothing fair about this.
And... you know, it's about winning.
>> COLBY: Jerri said, "Well, I don't want to draw names."
Tina said, "Why not?" She said, "I think we ought to
pick." She said "Who would you pick?"
She said "Colby." I'm sitting there going, well,
now hold on, let's think about who Colby would pick here.
Granted, I want to win this thing, but I don't know that I
want to share with her whatever it is.
>> JEFF: Come on in, guys. Today's reward challenge
is the biggest one yet. A helicopter is going to land at
Barramundi Beach and take you to one of the Seven Wonders of the
World-- the Great Barrier Reef. >> ELISABETH: Oh, my gosh.
>> JEFF: Where you'll go snorkeling in the clear blue
water, and you'll be treated to a great lunch.
The challenge is an obstacle course.
You and your partner must stay together.
There will be three heats with two teams competing.
It's simple elimination. If you win, you advance.
If you lose, you're out. The winners from the first two
heats will move on to the final. The winning team is going to the
Reef. You've already drawn straws to
see who's going to race first. You've picked your partners.
Let's go. This is heat number one.
Winners move onto the final round.
Survivors ready! Go!
>> JEFF: Nice job, Keith and Amber.
Take a break. Heat number two, winners will
take on Amber and Keith in the finals.
Survivors ready! Go!
>> JEFF: Way to go, Colby and Jerri.
Final heat, winners get a private helicopter ride to the
Great Barrier Reef. Here we go.
Survivors ready! Go!

>> KEITH: Just go... >> JERRI: Come on, pull!
>> COLBY: Hold on. >> JERRI: Ready?
( Colby grunting ) >> JERRI: Okay.
>> COLBY: Go. >> JERRI: No! Colby!

Hurry up! Go on, hurry up.
Hurry up, go. ( Jerri cries out )
>> JEFF: It's tight, it's tight. >> COLBY: You got it.

You got it! ( Jerri yells )

( Jerri yells ) >> AMBER: Come on, Keith!
>> COLBY: That a girl. >> JEFF: You guys are going to
the Great Barrier Reef. >> AMBER: Are you packing all

>> KEITH: Colby left an hour ago.
>> JERRI: He did not. They wouldn't do that.
That would be so cruel. >> ELISABETH: Yeah, that totally

>> KEITH: He tried to wake you, and you said no, you didn't want

they'd be here by now. >> AMBER: Me, too.
( engine whining ) >> TINA: Did y'all eat yet?
>> COLBY: Y'all could go ahead and start.
>> TINA: Well, you may be hungry before your trip.
You've got a long way to go. >> AMBER: But the helicopter is
going to be here any minute. ( helicopter blades whirring )
( Rodger yawning ) >> JERRI: There's got to be a
little, little bit of animosity and jealousy from everyone else
for winning two rewards in a row.
It bothers me a little bit 'cause I can see where that
might affect people's voting. But on the other hand, I really
couldn't give a flying crap, at this point.
( laughing ) >> TINA: Your limousine.
>> RODGER: Y'all have... y'all have fun.
Hope you... hope you get... >> ELISABETH: We want details.
>> AMBER: Make sure you remember everything you see.
>> JERRI: I will. >> COLBY: I can't believe he
just landed on our beach right there.
>> AMBER: I know. >> ELISABETH: For you guys.
>> So which of you two are coming for a fly with me today?
>> COLBY: We are. >> Yeah, my name's Craig.
>> COLBY: Colby. Nice to meet you, Craig.
>> CRAIG: Colby. >> JERRI: Jerri.
>> CRAIG: Jerri, how are you doing?
>> JERRI: Nice to meet you. >> CRAIG: Let's head out to the

Take note of everything. >> NICK: I don't want details.
>> AMBER: This is something they're going to remember for
the rest of their lives. >> NICK: I'll remember this
thing today, too. >> AMBER: Yeah, we will, too,
but... >> NICK: Watching the helicopter
go away. >> KEITH: Well, the kids are
gone for a day trip. >> NICK: Let's eat.
>> AMBER: Let's eat! >> ELISABETH: Let's eat.
>> CRAIG: We're getting over level stuff now, we'll go down
and have a look at the trees, and give you a bit of a close-up
look at the bush. >> COLBY: All right!
>> JERRI: Yee-haw! >> JERRI: We're in the middle of
nowhere. >> CRAIG: Oh, yeah.
As we come up on the river there, we're going to track
pretty much to the north, over some rugged outback stuff, so
have a good look around where you are.
>> COLBY: Sounds great. >> COLBY: Oh, yeah!
>> JERRI: Whoo! >> COLBY: I really got to get me
one of these choppers. >> CRAIG: Nice waterfalls up
ahead. >> JERRI: Wow!
>> CRAIG: Just a change of scenery.
>> COLBY: Just think, Jerri, we could be back on the beach
eating rice right now. >> JERRI: It was meant to be,
Colby. >> COLBY: I'm getting excited.
>> JERRI: We land on the beach and I see a boat sitting there.
I'm, like, "What is going on?" This is...
It couldn't possibly get any better.
( whoops ) I don't even want to think about
anybody right now. >> COLBY: No conversation about
strategy or Survivor today. >> JERRI: I can handle that.
>> COLBY: I told Jerri as soon as we got in the boat, I said,
"Here's the deal: No talk about the game, no
strategy, no talk about the other survivors.
Let's just enjoy the day for what it is: a day off...
and that's it. >> JERRI: Can't wait to get some
salt water in my hair. >> COLBY: Can't wait to get some
food in my belly. ( laughing )
>> JERRI: Wow! >> COLBY: Oh... no.
( Jerri gasps ) >> JERRI: Is that champagne?
>> COLBY: Looks like champagne to me.
>> JERRI: Oh, my God! >> COLBY: Bottled water.
>> JERRI: Oh, my God! >> COLBY: Underwater cameras.
Look at this. >> JERRI: Unbelievable!
>> COLBY: Look at all this! >> JERRI: We get under this tent
and there is just this spread. There's a basket full of all
different kinds of fruits, wrapped sandwiches, a bag of
Doritos... there's pasta salad and sweet potatoes and all these
different vegetables. >> COLBY: Look at this...
>> JERRI: A day at the beach! >> COLBY: Look at what you get
here-- a little brownie. >> JERRI: Oh!
>> COLBY: I know. Gol-lee!
>> JERRI: Where do we start? >> COLBY: Where do we start?
>> JERRI: Perfect. >> COLBY: I feel rather spoiled
right now. >> JERRI: We got champagne over
there. >> COLBY: That'd be cool.
We don't need to have alcohol, if we're going diving.
( Jerri laughs ) >> JERRI: Sure we do.
( cork pops ) We just... we feasted for
a good while, and then realized, "I wonder how
everybody else is doing?" But I knew.
>> AMBER: Around camp, we just kind of did, you know, daily
chores and stuff. Keith and I went and got some
firewood and broke some firewood up.
Just normal taking care of our camp stuff, you know, and not
too exciting, but just enough to keep us busy to make the day go
by a little bit faster with nothing to do.
Oh, no... he only said little things-- I think he's just
really enjoying himself. Just... you know...
Why not? >> NICK: Just to get out of here
and see one of the wonders of the world would have been great.
We're in the outback, but we're seeing, you know, the same basic
spot over and over and over. So to get out and see some
really clear blue water and have a big meal, it would've been
great. >> JERRI: Here we are in the
middle of the Great Barrier Reef.
It was just too close to paradise.
The setting-- it was very, very romantic, on top of everything
else. I even looked at him at one
point and I was, like, "This is one hell of a first date,
Colby." I couldn't have come out here
with a better person than Colby. We're having a great time.
We're getting to know each other outside of the game and outside
of that environment. This is basically the perfect
honeymoon without the sex. >> COLBY: Jerri was quite giddy
on our little getaway. >> JERRI: Mmm!
>> COLBY: She made a comment to me about it being a honeymoon
without the sex, and it couldn't be farther from the truth for
me. I mean, we certainly didn't sit
around and high five and say, "Man, we finally get our time
alone together," you know? That's not what I was looking
for. I was just looking for some down
time away from the game and that's what I got.
I do not want to leave here. >> JERRI: I don't, either.
>> COLBY: It's hard back on Barramundi Beach, being out
there 26 days going on a month, and not have anything but rice,
so we're just going to go back in and try to be as humble as
possible about it. If somebody pisses me off, then
I'm going to just say, "I got to go snorkeling on the Great
Barrier Reef. What did you do today?"
>> JERRI: Returning to Barramundi right now is...
I'm not really looking forward to it.
But I at least am going back feeling rejuvenated and renewed
and a little bit more like my true self.
Because, man, after 26 days of putting on the game face and
being this tough, you know, "don't mess with me" chick--
but I got a tender side, too. I feel like a little bit of that
was touched today. >> KEITH: Well, let's see what
this noise is here. That chopper is definitely
coming. Yep, there it is.
Here they are. >> ELISABETH: Where?
>> KEITH: Right coming over the trees.
Right there. >> ELISABETH: There they are.
>> Yeah. We want details.
>> JERRI: That was awesome. >> AMBER: Your meal?
What was your meal? >> JERRI: Start out...
>> COLBY: Bananas, apples and oranges.
>> Mmm. >> Mmm.
>> JERRI: A couple of nectarines.
>> COLBY: And a couple of nectarines.
I wish everyone could have come with us.
>> ELISABETH: Good jump start. You got a jump start.
>> JERRI: Yeah. >> COLBY: But since you

( laughter ) Everybody gets their own piece

>> Oh! >> AMBER: How exciting!
>> TINA: Wow. That's very nice of you to do,

>> COLBY: Here's your, uh, orange for Tennessee.

I find him and myself to be the most even on the playing field,

>> ELISABETH: Colby, thank you so much.

>> NICK: Hey, Keith, can you grab the funnel?
>> COLBY: Immunity is going to determine who goes next time,
just like immunity determined who... who's going tonight.
Nick comes over from Kucha, and as Ogakor, we're still trying to
maintain some sort of control. We determined a long time ago
that Nick was more of a threat than say Elisabeth and Rodger.
So that determines why Nick goes before them.
>> ELISABETH: Suckers. >> RODGER: That's it.
( clattering in box ) >> NICK: Oh, I need some water.
>> RODGER: Grasshopper's in the box!
>> KEITH: Nick's a strong guy, although Nick's pretty much had
it. He's-He's burned out, and he
says, "Listen, I'm rea... You know, I'm ready to go."
So, I don't feel real bad about that.
>> ELISABETH: I don't think we've been alone together in a

>> RODGER: You're right. >> ELISABETH: The remaining
Kucha survivors. >> RODGER: This wind's blowing

I know Nick feels as if he's probably the next to go out of
our tribe, but if he wins immunity, it could just as
easily be me or Rodger. >> NICK: If I don't win the
immunity challenge, I think I'm a goner.
I'll go boil water. >> RODGER: Well, maybe that's
why. They...
>> ELISABETH: We slave away in the outback...

>> AMBER: Oh, wow. >> Oh!
>> JERRI: "Those with good balance are in for a treat,

sure on their feet." >> JERRI: "If you keep steady

>> KEITH: From time to time. >> JEFF: Put it back on its
perch. Are you predicting another
victory today? >> KEITH: Ah, I don't know.
>> JEFF: You're going to have to share the wealth.
>> KEITH: Luck is on my side. >> JEFF: All right.
Today's immunity challenge is going to test your balance, not
your strength. In fact, one of the keys is
figuring out how to use your opponent's strength against them
to knock them off balance. There will be three rounds.
Each round's a different challenge.
It's single elimination. Lose, you're out.
Win, you move on. First round, you'll climb up
onto the towers, one against another, and using a rope,
you're going to try and knock your opponent off balance into
the water. It's not a tug of war.
You can pull on the rope, or if you want, just let it go.
Next round, you have a shaky beam.
So, it's all about using your legs and redistributing weight
to get them forward or backwards.
>> AMBER: Wow. >> JEFF: For the last round, the
